You can figure out what's suitable, what works for you, what doesn't. That's all good. The hope is just to share ideas and information. Now the options expiration for today was a little bit lighter because this wasn't the densest series that exists right now when I say series, I just mean expiration cycle. So here we can see that the total open interest here was 140,000 calls and 58,000 puts, which is actually a little bit on the lighter side. Now if we take a look at 20 dees, you can see that it's 108 at 42. The interesting thing is that the 17 Jan is the spicy one so far. This is where people are positioning. And again, I continue to highlight things as I see them, which is important in that this is relatively new for GameStop. Typically speaking, we see so much of the total open interest in the front expirations. This has been about a month now that we've continually seen. So I a little further out in time. Now it was up to 60 days out when I first started noticing it. Now obviously the 17 Jan's about 35 days expiration, but that's where most of this is, which is again, really interesting just because it's slightly different. One of the things that you'll notice when we do any sort of options analysis or stock analysis for that perspective is you have to build a baseline understanding of what you're looking at. What is normal is entirely relative to the stock that you're looking at. So for example, GameStop, it's pretty normal at this point to have call OI exceed put OI. If we take a look at something else by comparison like spy, you'll notice it's the inverse. You almost always will see put OI exceed call OI. So you have to understand the individual ticker that you're looking at because there's unique qualities. This to me is not worthy not because calls exceed puts. Again, that's generally the standard here, but it's that the ratio between these, that's now what I track for GameStop because I've identified that as

Now what I can tell you because I've made videos about Max Payne, I've studied it pretty extensively not just from GameStop, but just as a general phenomenon, which is interesting. And again, rightfully so because most of it came from interest earned on their cash horde, which is great. But again, from a trader investor perspective, we don't necessarily want to see a company making a bunch of money from holding cash that happens to earn a yield because rates are high right now. We want to see sales revenue. We want to see the business growing. So that's not to belittle the earnings. The earnings was great. It was a slight beat, which is awesome. But I still think that's why we didn't see that beat lead to some sort of massive move because I do think as we start to see GameStop have stronger earnings as it continues to evolve. I absolutely expect to see things like post earnings announcement drift exist in something like this. text: see GameStop have stronger earnings as it continues to evolve. I absolutely expect to see things like post earnings announcement drift exist in something like this. And for those that are unfamiliar, I have a couple videos that talk about post earnings announcement drift. But post earnings announcement drift tends to happen when you have a company that has a big earnings beat. So if you take a look here, the earnings was 95 cents. It came in at a dollar 25. That's a big beat. And then it's typically followed if it's going to exhibit post earnings announcement drift to the positive side. It's typically coupled with a gap, right? So it typically means that there's some sort of really new news that's led to repricing and reevaluation of the value of a stock. And that tends to carry out over time because it's not immediately priced in big, big sources of money take some time to move around. So that's post earnings announcement drift. And I would not be surprised at all to see GameStop start exhibiting that once it starts having slightly stronger earnings. But I think that's why even though they had a beat in this instance, it didn't necessarily drive post earnings announcement drift one way or the other because of that. So back to the option chain, we have really light volatility. I mean, it's essentially sub 100 across all of it. The front is always going to be jacked up. But the next

Now, the other thing that I did see people talking about with some of these 125s, one of the things to know with something like the 125 strikes is for a lot of different entities. This is used for managing risk. We call it units, unit building. And it's because you can buy a lot of options for a little amount of money that will have lower overall extrinsic value, although on a relative basis that they did a cable be very high. If you have no idea what I just said, listen to it a couple times. And then you can reach out to us and the discord is completely free to join. But that's an important point. Now, this does not surprise me at all. And this is also a big reason why we continue to see the far out of the money's being populated both by my expectation, being institutions and retail traders alike. Now, for the retail trading perspective, it's typically a tough position to take on because retail traders tend to have smaller bank rolls. So then when they put on these positions that are very low hit rate, that's the nature of this style trade. This is the kind of trade that you put on 100 times and you expect it to hit twice, something like that. Now, for a smaller retail trader, if you put this on 100 times and you miss 60 something in a row, that can erode your bank roll, depending on how you're sizing the trades. For larger institutions, they literally amortize out how many times they expect to hit on some sort of move that they can monetize to make sure that they're positively expected. But the only way you can achieve that kind of risk reward profile and positive expected return from this is to have a large enough bank roll and size appropriately, which I think a lot of retail traders, unfortunately, don't do.
